docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 26 front-page article on the discovery of the genetic mutation causing colorectal cancer among Ashkenazi Jews underplays the risks of genetic tests. Surveys document the reality of health insurance discrimination against genetic disease carriers. Losing health insurance would be a terrible price to pay for discovering that you need to take pre-emptive health measures like colonoscopies. Passage of a bill sponsored by Representative Louise M. Slaughter would protect individuals against losing insurance as they seek the care they need. MARLENE E. POST National President, Hadassah New York, Aug. 26, 1997

headline.main: Insurance for Back Pain Ignores the Real Issue

docs.abstract: Marlene E Post letter contends that Aug 26 article on discovery of genetic mutation causing colorectal cancer among Ashkenazi Jews underplays risks of genetic tests; says surveys document reality of health insurance discrimination against genetic disease; supports Rep Louise M Slaughter bill that would protect individuals against losing insurance as they seek care they need

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gov. George E. Pataki should be ashamed for signing the bill requiring insurers to pay for chiropractic care, while refusing to guarantee access to basic medical care, including approved clinical trials and the use of ''off label'' drugs -- those not approved by the Food and Drug Administration (news article, Aug. 22).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 22 news article on the merger of a for-profit health maintenance organization and Fidelis Care New York, an H.M.O. sponsored by the eight Roman Catholic dioceses of New York, neglected to note that Fidelis does not provide family planning care to members. Forty thousand patients will be denied contraceptive services and abortion coverage. Fidelis is not required to publicize this lack of coverage to enrollees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumer Optimism Bolsters Growth Outlook Reports hinted that consumer spending could remain strong for the rest of the year, driving further strong economic growth. The Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index rose to 129.1 points this month from 126.3 in July, bouncing back near the 28-year high seen in June. Orders for durable goods eased by six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Government said, but analysts saw underlying strength in the report. Yet another report showed that sales of existing single-family homes rose in July. $(Page D2.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: The merger of two of Long Island's largest hospitals would produce only $6.2 million a year in savings, not the $92 million in annual savings projected by the hospitals, a witness for the Federal Government testified in Federal court here today. The witness, Dr. Robert Taylor, an efficiencies expert, also estimated that the merger would save less than $1 million in capital expenses, compared with the one-time savings of $78 million projected by financial analysts for the two hospitals, Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems.

headline.main: Analyst Disputes the Savings Projected in a Hospital Merger

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Taylor, efficiencies expert, testifies that merger of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems would produce only $6.2 million a year in savings, not $92 million in annual savings projected by hospitals; Justice Dept is trying to block merger, contending that it would violate antitrust laws (M)
docs.snippet: The merger of two of Long Island's largest hospitals would produce only $6.2 million a year in savings, not the $92 million in annual savings projected by the hospitals, a witness for the Federal Government testified in Federal court here today.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Union of American Physicians and Dentists, one of the nation's few independent doctors' unions, plans to announce today that it will join forces with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, more than doubling the federation's physician membership. In balloting that was to be completed yesterday, 90 percent of the 5,000 members of the doctors union are expected to approve teaming up with the federation, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s second-largest affiliate, to draw on its resources for lobbying, organizing and negotiating contracts with insurers, said Gary R. Robinson, the executive director of the doctors' union.

headline.main: Union for Doctors to Join Forces With Government Workers

docs.abstract: Union of American Physicians and Dentists, which represents about 20 percent of California's practicing doctors, plans to join forces with American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents about 3,000 doctors in dozen states; will draw on its resources for lobbying, organizing and negotiating contracts with insurers (M)/

docs.lead_paragraph: Great-West Lifeco Inc., Canada's largest group life and health insurer, said today that it had raised its offer to buy London Insurance Group and that the companies had signed an agreement to prevent other bids. Great-West, which is controlled by the Power Corporation of Montreal, made the announcement a week after it outbid Royal Bank of Canada for London Insurance, which is another big Canadian insurer. Great-West will pay $34 a share (Canadian), 50 cents more than it offered last week, for all the shares of London Insurance. The new agreement values London Insurance, 57 percent of which is owned by the Trilon Financial Corporation, at $2.94 billion (Canadian), or $2.1 billion (United States).

headline.main: Higher Bid Seals Insurance Deal in Canada

docs.abstract: Great-West Lifeco Inc, Canada's largest group life and health insurer, says it raised its offer to buy London Insurance Group and that companies signed agreement to prevent other bids; new agreement is valued at $2.1 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration has reached an agreement to let a private group of doctors operate a major hospital network in the Bronx, the first time that a large public teaching hospital in New York City would not be run by a private hospital or medical school. Under the unusual arrangement, worked out in principle on Friday, the city will pay a group of about 375 doctors $253 million over three years to operate Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital, which together are known as the North Bronx Health Care Network. To handle the hospital's business matters, like billing and writing checks, the doctors will use a private management company that performs the same function at the city's Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn.

headline.main: Doctors Win Pact to Run City Hospitals

docs.abstract: New York City will pay group of about 375 doctors $253 million over three years to operate Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital, which together are known as North Bronx Health Care Network; it is first time that large public teaching hospital in New York City will not be run by private hospital or medical school; most of doctors in group have worked for years at two hospitals, which have been operated until recently by Montefiore Medical Center; city terminated Montefiore's contract in June (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a discovery that offers a new way of preventing many cases of colon cancer, biologists have detected a genetic change that apparently doubles the risk of the disease. The genetic change, or mutation, occurs in as many as 6 percent of people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, according to preliminary studies, making it the most common known cancer gene in a particular population. The mutation has not yet been found among non-Ashkenazis.

headline.main: Gene Mutation Tied To Colon Cancers In Ashkenazi Jews

docs.abstract: Johns Hopkins University researchers discover genetic mutation that apparently doubles risk of colon cancer in people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent; have developed test to detect it; mutation occurs in as many as 6 percent of Ashkenazi Jews, making it most common cancer gene in particular population; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: * Seabury & Smith, Fort Washington, Pa., a unit of Marsh & McLennan Inc., to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, as the first agency to handle integrated marketing for the health insurance products of the American Association of Retired Persons. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million. * Cox Interactive Media, Atlanta, a division of Cox Enterprises Inc., to K2 Design, New York, as the first interactive agency of record, handling on-line creative and media duties. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.
